column1: Polynomial regular expression used on uncontrolled data
column2: A regular expression that can require polynomial time to match may be vulnerable to denial-of-service attacks.
column4: This [["regular expression"|"relative:///lib/xiki/tools/twitter.rb:41:26:41:27"]] that depends on a [["user-provided value"|"relative:///lib/xiki/tools/twitter.rb:35:17:35:101"]] may run slow on strings starting with '<title>' and with many repetitions of '<title>a'.

column2: Matching HTML tags using regular expressions is hard to do right, and can easily lead to security issues.
column4: This regular expression only parses --> and not --!> as a HTML comment end tag.

column2: Overly permissive regular expression ranges match a wider range of characters than intended. This may allow an attacker to bypass a filter or sanitizer.
column4: Suspicious character range that is equivalent to [+,\-.\/0-9:;<=>?].

column1: Use of `Kernel.open` or `IO.read` or similar sinks with a non-constant value
column2: Using `Kernel.open`, `IO.read`, `IO.write`, `IO.binread`, `IO.binwrite`, `IO.foreach`, `IO.readlines`, or `URI.open` may allow a malicious user to execute arbitrary system commands.
